Four-year-old RJ Jackson has Netherton's syndrome, an extremely rare congenital skin disease affecting only about 70 people worldwide. The condition causes his skin to appear red, inflamed, and scaly. His mother, Valerie Jackson from Las Vegas, must regularly apply creams to prevent his skin from drying out. Due to RJ's appearance, his mother has faced significant public misconceptions, including being reported to police for suspected child abuse while shopping at Walmart. The family has also experienced discrimination, such as being denied entry to play centers, and endures cruel comments from adults. Netherton's syndrome is a genetic condition that appears at birth, causing red, scaly skin and requiring constant care. While there is no cure, symptoms can improve with time, though patients continue to have sensitive, red, and scaly skin throughout their lives.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Transport for London (TfL) announced the removal of controversial Protein World advertisements featuring a bikini-clad model with the slogan "Are you beach body ready?" The ads, which appeared in the London Underground, sparked significant backlash from feminists and body image campaigners, with over 50,000 people signing a petition for their removal and many posters being defaced. The Advertising Standards Authority received more than 200 complaints about the ads promoting unhealthy body image. While TfL confirmed the removal, they clarified it was due to the end of the scheduled three-week advertising period. Protein World defended their campaign despite receiving threats, including a bomb threat under police investigation. The controversy generated significant social media debate, with some supporting the company's stance while others condemned it as promoting unrealistic body standards.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Rail companies are planning significant fare increases of up to 87% just ten days after the general election, despite political promises to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has requested First Great Western (FGW) review their decision to nearly double some fares between London and the Cotswolds, which affects his Witney constituency. A specific example shows tickets from Charlbury to London increasing from £33.30 to £62.40 for off-peak returns. Other rail companies are also implementing price hikes, including London Midlands and Virgin Trains, though Virgin claims their overall increase is only 1.65%. The changes affect unregulated fares, which make up about half of rail companies' revenue, and include off-peak leisure and advance-purchase tickets. FGW states the changes are to standardize pricing across their routes and offers cheaper advance booking options.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

John Young, a 66-year-old former soldier, was blinded in his left eye after being attacked at his home in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The incident occurred around 11 PM on April 18, just three weeks after his wedding to Elaine Young, 54. The couple were writing thank you cards for their wedding gifts when vandals began throwing stones at their front window. When Mr. Young opened his front door to confront the attackers, he was struck in the face with a brick, resulting in permanent blindness in his left eye despite emergency surgery. Police are investigating the incident but say there appears to be no clear motive, suggesting it might have been youths "messing around." The couple, feeling unsafe, have decided to relocate to Southport following the attack.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Tom Poynton, Derbyshire's 25-year-old wicketkeeper, has signed a one-year contract extension following his successful return from injury. He missed the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries from a road accident that tragically claimed his father Keith's life in April. After undergoing ankle surgery, Poynton made his comeback during the team's pre-season tour in Abu Dhabi and will be available for the start of the season, now committed to the county until the end of 2016. The team's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's character and dedication to his recovery, both in training and off-field duties.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. During his treatment, which included 80 days of chemotherapy, surgery to remove a kidney tumor, and radiotherapy, Harley decorated a protective mask like a Ninja Turtle to help him feel brave during his radiotherapy sessions. His story gained attention, leading to gifts from Nickelodeon and a Cancer Research UK Little Star award. After a year of treatment, including a stem cell transplant, Harley was declared cancer-free by doctors. Neuroblastoma is a rare cancer affecting fewer than 100 children in the UK annually, typically occurring in children under five years old, and involves specialized nerve cells in the nervous system.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Tim Sherwood, Aston Villa's manager, advises 19-year-old Jack Grealish to focus on his club career before deciding his international future between England and the Republic of Ireland. Following Grealish's impressive performance in Villa's 2-1 FA Cup semi-final victory over Liverpool, Sherwood emphasizes that Grealish needs to establish himself in Villa's first team before making his international choice. Sherwood draws parallels to a similar situation he faced with Nabil Bentaleb at Tottenham, who chose between France and Algeria. Grealish's father Kevin agrees with Sherwood's advice, stating that his son needs to maintain good club performances before addressing international commitments. The player is expected to make his decision between Ireland and England at the end of the season, and is currently undecided between the two countries.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

The text discusses airport landing fees for private jets, highlighting the most expensive airports globally. Private jet travel is a growing industry worth $16.7 trillion in the US and $15.8 trillion in Europe, with 2.5 million private flights in the US (2013) and 705,000 in Europe.

The top three most expensive airports for landing fees (based on 767-400 aircraft) are all in Japan:
1. Haneda Airport (Tokyo) - £4,559
2. Narita International Airport (Tokyo) - £3,728
3. Kansai International Airport (Osaka) - £3,594

Other notable expensive airports include Toronto Pearson, Darwin International, Bristol Airport (UK's only entry), and La Guardia (only US entry). Peak private jet usage occurs during major sporting events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix, with trips costing up to $54,000 for long-range jets. Popular routes include Los Angeles to Las Vegas and Milan to Rome in Europe.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Katie Gallegos from Oregon took her two dogs, Cooper (a Labrador) and Daisy (a smaller female dog), to McDonald's for ice cream. While Daisy took small, careful licks, Cooper devoured his portion in one bite. The video of this event went viral with over seven million views. Though some viewers criticized Gallegos for feeding ice cream to her dogs, she defended the practice, noting that Cooper is healthy and athletic, and that her previous dog lived to 19 years old despite having weekly ice cream treats. The dogs are also known to visit Starbucks for "pup-uccinos" (whipped cream in a cup), where Cooper displays the same eager eating habits. Gallegos, who runs a dog resort, ensures Daisy gets limited portions due to her smaller size.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Gary Locke has been appointed as Kilmarnock's permanent manager on a three-year contract after serving as interim manager. He initially joined the club as assistant manager to Allan Johnston in summer 2014, before taking over when Johnston left in February. Under Locke's interim leadership, the team performed well, losing only one out of seven games. The 41-year-old manager finalized the deal with chairman Jim Mann.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, is in conflict with Seminole County Elementary School over her 5-year-old autistic son Logan's use of essential oils. The school threatened to suspend Logan because the DoTerra oils he wears, including lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood, were deemed distracting to other students. Kemp applies the oils to her son's head and neck, believing they help keep him calm and focused. While the school board sent a letter stating the oils created a "problem" for staff and students, the Lake County School District later clarified they would not suspend Logan, describing it as a "health issue." Despite the controversy, Kemp maintains she will continue fighting for her son's right to use the oils.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

A fire destroyed a 90-unit beachside condominium complex called Sandpiper in Westhampton Beach on Wednesday at 3 PM. The blaze was so intense that it melted paint off nearby buildings and could be seen from three miles away. Twelve fire crews responded but were unable to enter the building, which eventually collapsed. The complex, which operates seasonally from May to November, was completely destroyed. The building manager, Rob Taber, who lived and worked there, lost everything. Fire officials are investigating the cause, with initial reports suggesting the fire may have started near a parked car. Fortunately, due to offshore winds, firefighters had good visibility to combat the blaze from the front of the structure.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

The passage describes Queen Elizabeth II, aged 88, riding her black fell pony named Carltonlima Emma in Windsor Great Park. The Queen notably refuses to wear a riding helmet, preferring silk scarves, reportedly due to concerns about her hair. She has been a lifelong equestrian enthusiast, having received her first pony, a Shetland named Peggy, at age four. While she has reduced her riding in recent years due to a knee injury, she remains actively involved in horse breeding, including fell ponies at Hampton Court. The passage also provides historical context about fell ponies, describing them as one of the oldest equine breeds, originating from Cumbria. These ponies, typically black, grey, or bay in color, have evolved from ancient times through Roman and Viking periods, serving various purposes from pack animals to modern-day riding horses.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

A fatal incident occurred between two Brisbane neighbors over noise levels. Leon Yeaman, 55, was allegedly killed by a single punch from his neighbor Phillip Pama, 28, during a confrontation. The incident happened when Yeaman was making noise in his yard around 9 PM while Pama, a shift worker and father of three, was trying to sleep before his 3 AM work shift. According to Pama's lawyer, Yeaman was known for being drunk and playing loud music. During the confrontation, Pama allegedly threw a blind punch while being pushed, which resulted in Yeaman's death. Paramedics pronounced Yeaman dead at the scene around 11 PM. Pama was charged with manslaughter and granted conditional bail, requiring him to surrender his passport, follow a curfew, and report to police regularly. The case is scheduled to return to court on May 18.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old Russian music teacher, attempted to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old former student, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship for a classmate. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the hit. Police conducted a sting operation where an undercover officer posed as a hitman and secretly filmed Simonova ordering the hit. During the meeting, she requested that the "hitman" severely beat the boy, break his limbs, and damage his kidneys, wanting him to suffer before she would "finish him." After providing expense money, she was arrested by police and charged with attempted murder, facing up to 15 years in prison. Prior to this, Simonova had maintained a year-long relationship with the student, during which she showered him with gifts and money.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Jose Mourinho, the 52-year-old Chelsea football manager, revealed that he has a strong religious faith and prays to God daily, but never about football. He only attends church regularly when in Portugal and goes elsewhere when he feels the need. While maintaining an aggressive persona in his professional life, Mourinho describes himself as a good family person and friend. He keeps his professional and family life separate, and despite his competitive nature in football, he believes he's a good person who supports others. The passage also mentions that Mourinho and his family have worked with the World Food Programme as ambassadors against hunger. At the time, Chelsea was leading the league, and Mourinho had recently been fined £25,000 for claiming there was a "campaign" against Chelsea.

The passage describes Bob Barker's brief return to hosting "The Price is Right" on April 1, after an eight-year absence. At age 91, Barker, who had hosted the show for 35 years before retiring in 2007, returned to host the "Lucky Seven" segment before handing the show back to current host Drew Carey. Despite his long absence, Barker performed smoothly in his temporary return to the show.

Based on the passage, here's a concise summary of the core information:

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested at 12:30 AM on Friday in Washington D.C. for attempted burglary and destruction of property. The incident occurred on the 3200 block of D Street SE. Following his arrest, the Secret Service revoked Baldwin's security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin worked in the foreign missions branch, which is connected to the State Department and diplomatic activities. This incident adds to recent troubles for the Secret Service, coming just two days after another supervisor was put on leave for misconduct, and following a March 4 incident where two high-ranking officials allegedly drove into a secure White House area after drinking.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

A 38-year-old freelance photographer, Atif Saeed from Lahore, Pakistan, took an extremely risky photograph of a male lion at the city's safari park. He left his car and approached within 10 feet of the lion, lying on the ground to capture the shot. The sound of the camera's shutter alerted the lion, causing it to charge at Saeed, who barely managed to escape back to his car. While Saeed was initially amused by the encounter, he later acknowledged the dangerous nature of his actions and doubted he would attempt such a feat again.

The core information includes:
- Who: Atif Saeed, 38, freelance photographer
- Where: Safari park in Lahore, Pakistan
- What: Extremely close-up photography of a lion
- Distance: 10 feet from the lion
- Outcome: Lion charged after hearing camera shutter, photographer escaped to car
- Photographer's reflection: Wouldn't attempt it again

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

A woman was found unconscious and later pronounced dead on March 22 in Brooklyn's Gravesend area near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue. The unidentified woman, estimated to be between 25-45 years old, had no identification but had a distinctive tattoo on her right leg featuring the name "Monique" within a heart design topped with a rose. The NYPD released images of the tattoo hoping to identify her, including both the current faded version and an artist's rendering of its original appearance. The cause of death is still pending a medical examiner's report, and police are seeking public assistance through their Crime Stoppers hotline.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009 because they couldn't afford traditional property. The construction took about a year and a half, resulting in a two-bedroom house made of wood and steel. The home is largely self-sufficient, powered by solar panels, with water from a spring and gas for the stove and hot water. Located in Nelson, New Zealand, the house features cypress wood interiors, stained glass windows, and cost approximately $25,000 to build. The couple now lives there with their cat, surrounded by nature, with their first power bill being only $25. The home includes two bedrooms, with one being a loft space used as a spare room.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Research conducted by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University found that kindergarten students who shared iPads in class performed significantly better on early literacy tests compared to both students who had individual iPads and those who didn't use iPads at all. The study, involving 352 students in a Midwestern suburban school district, showed that students sharing iPads scored approximately 30 points higher than the other groups. The researcher concluded that the collaborative learning experience around the technology, rather than just collaboration itself, was responsible for the improved performance, suggesting that schools should reconsider how tablets are used in early education.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

A piglet born without back legs in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on its front two legs. Owned by farmer Ms. Duan, the piglet has mastered balancing on its front trotters despite being born without hind legs. A video shows the animal wobbling and foraging for food while maintaining its balance, and it lives normally among its four-legged siblings. The story has attracted many villagers to see the unusual animal, and it's not the first two-legged animal to gain attention in China, as a similar case involved a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo that learned to walk on its front paws.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, pit crew member Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when driver Francesco Dracone's car hit him during a pit stop on lap 25. Dracone spun while exiting his pit box, striking Phillips' leg. Phillips was treated at the infield care center, received stitches for a leg cut, and was released. The race conditions were challenging due to rain, and Dracone ultimately finished 23rd in the race.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

A 32-year-old man named Milton Vieira Severiano killed his 29-year-old wife, Cicera Alves de Sena (stage name Amanda Bueno), a dancer in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. CCTV footage captured him dragging her into their apartment's garden, smashing her head into concrete 11 times, punching her 10 times, and then shooting her in the face five times. The incident occurred just four days after their wedding, following an argument where he accused her of being unfaithful. After the murder, Severiano attempted to flee in a stolen car but was caught by police after crashing. He confessed to the murder, citing jealousy over men looking at his wife as his motive. Police found multiple weapons in his car, including four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest. He now faces life imprisonment.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Sarah Wilson, a 41-year-old journalist and author of "I Quit Sugar," revealed her personal struggle with mental illness in an interview with Women's Weekly Australia. She discussed reaching a point where she contemplated suicide due to a combination of factors including stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and family isolation. Wilson felt particularly alone due to not having a husband or children. While she struggled in her younger years feeling like she had "missed out on a guide book to life," she has recently found more peace with her condition. She believes depression and anxiety are interconnected and emphasizes the need to recognize this connection to address the rising rates of anxiety among Australian women. According to Beyond Blue, one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Elena Curtin, a seven-months pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault in November 2014 after beating her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar. The incident occurred when Curtin found the ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom and refusing to leave. Prosecutors ultimately dropped the charges, considering Curtin's actions "justified" under Oregon law, which permits use of physical force against intruders who won't leave. The ex-girlfriend had a history of harassing Curtin and shared a five-year-old child with the boyfriend. Following the incident, Curtin gave birth in January and moved in with her parents, while the boyfriend, who has struggled with heroin addiction, is not involved in their child's life.

The passage describes a pit bull named Gemma from California who was filmed being fed treats by her owner. When her owner sneakily included a piece of broccoli among the treats, Gemma showed disgust upon eating it and spat it out on the floor. The passage mentions that Gemma lives with two children and, when not eating, enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

HSBC experienced an embarrassing incident where a link on their official website redirected visitors to a pornographic website. This occurred because a webpage originally used for their Young Entrepreneur Awards, which ended in 2011, had its domain registration expire. When the registration lapsed, the URL was taken over by a porn site. After discovering the error, HSBC removed the hyperlink from their main website and issued a public apology on April 20, emphasizing they had no association with the external site. The bank assured that their website remained secure throughout the incident.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

A 13-year-old boy named Marcus and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah were trapped in a second-floor bedroom during a house fire in Clinton, Maryland. Marcus called 911 before 7 AM and remained calm during an 11-minute call, providing clear directions to firefighters while comforting his sister. Prince George's County firefighters rescued the siblings by entering through a broken window. Lt. Kenny Ward, a 25-year veteran firefighter, helped Marcus out and gave his gas mask to Aaliyah. The siblings were taken to children's hospital with non-life threatening injuries, while three other family members (mother, step-father, and older brother) escaped on their own and were taken to Medstar hospital.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Blue fluorescent algae created a spectacular light display along Australia's east coast at Jervis Bay, NSW. The phenomenon was captured by photographer Andy Hutchinson, who described it as a "beautiful supernatural scene." The glow is caused by a single-celled phytoplankton called noctiluca scintillans, which according to University of NSW expert Iain Suthers, typically blooms in spring and autumn. The organism produces this luminous effect as a defense mechanism, and in 90% of cases, it occurs naturally. A similar display was previously observed at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

New genetic tests are being developed that can help breast cancer patients determine whether they need chemotherapy after surgery. These tests analyze tumor cells to assess the risk of cancer recurrence. For some women, the tests can show a risk as low as 5% without chemotherapy, which is comparable to or better than the odds with chemotherapy.

Currently, most breast cancer patients routinely receive chemotherapy after tumor removal, despite its severe side effects like hair loss, nausea, and extreme fatigue. One of these new tests, called EndoPredict, costs about £2,500 and is mostly available privately, though there are hopes it will become available through the NHS.

The passage includes a specific case study of Becca Cornford, a mother of three, who used the EndoPredict test. Her results showed a low 5% chance of recurrence within ten years, allowing her to avoid chemotherapy while maintaining confidence in her treatment decision.

Medical professionals quoted in the passage support these tests, suggesting they allow for more informed treatment choices rather than the current approach of giving chemotherapy to almost everyone.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, with HMS Ocean having five such evacuations over nine years. The evacuations occurred across eighteen different ships, including HMS Illustrious (nicknamed 'HMS Lusty'). The Ministry of Defence maintains a strict 'no touching' rule at sea, suggesting pregnancies occurred before boarding or during leave periods.

The passage also mentions that women have served in the Royal Navy since 1990, with females making up 9% of personnel as of 2014. Additionally, between 2006 and 2013, 99 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan due to pregnancy, and 102 were evacuated from Iraq. Military rules prohibit pregnant women from serving in war zones, though pregnancy tests are not mandatory before deployment.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

A drone containing traces of radioactive cesium was discovered on the rooftop of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence in Tokyo. The drone was equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing the radioactive material. While the amount of cesium wasn't immediately harmful to humans, the incident raised terrorism concerns, particularly regarding future events like the Olympics and G7 summit. The discovery coincided with a court's approval to restart two nuclear reactors at the Sendai power plant, a controversial decision given Japan's nuclear concerns following the Fukushima disaster. At the time of the incident, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was in Indonesia, and Japanese law had no flight restrictions for drones in most of Tokyo, including government buildings.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang province, China, takes his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's, to work with him daily on his motorbike. He began this routine after his father's death because there was no one else to care for her - his wife works in another city and his son is in school. To ensure his mother's safety, he ties a sash around both their waists during the four-kilometer journey, which takes an hour. His employer, a bank, has provided a room for his mother while he works. Lu does this to prevent his mother from getting lost, which happened several times before when she was alone collecting firewood. He views this as his duty to repay his mother's devotion in raising him and his siblings.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

A study by the University of Washington found that heavy drinking in America increased by 17.2% between 2005-2012, primarily driven by women's drinking habits. By 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers. Women's binge drinking rates increased more than seven times the rate of men over the decade.

The CDC defines heavy drinking as exceeding one drink per day for women and two for men, while binge drinking is four or more drinks for women and five or more for men on a single occasion per month.

The study, which was the first to track adult drinking at the county level, found significant regional variations. Contributing factors to the increase include changing social norms for women, cheaper alcohol prices relative to inflation, increased alcohol advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies. In 2010, alcohol was attributed to 88,600 U.S. deaths, with excessive drinking estimated to cost over $220 billion annually.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

UN officials are warning that doctors are performing too many caesarean sections, putting women and babies at risk. While the current rate in England is over 25% (doubled since the 1990s), the World Health Organization recommends it should only be between 10-15%. The WHO emphasizes that caesareans should only be performed when medically necessary, as they can lead to complications, infections, and even death. The procedure is also more expensive, costing the NHS £2,369 compared to £1,665 for natural births. This WHO stance conflicts with current NHS guidelines, which allow caesareans for non-medical reasons, including anxiety about childbirth (tokophobia). Research indicates that about 10% of caesareans result in infections.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Michelle Filkins, 44, was arrested on April 17 after breaking into and living in a Martha's Vineyard home owned by Mark Conklin. She was discovered by Conklin sitting in his living room of the $800,000 property, where she falsely claimed ownership before fleeing. During her stay, Filkins allegedly sold or gave away numerous items from the home in a yard sale, including furniture from Crate & Barrel and Ethan Allen, a Weber grill, lamps, and artwork. She was charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. The police are now requesting that anyone who received items from the home return them to the Edgartown Police Department, noting that purchasers are also victims and may seek restitution through court prosecution.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

A woman named Bella Crooke from Melbourne lost her unlocked iPhone at a birthday party. The phone was handed in to Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border. The police officers, noticing the phone was unlocked, posted several humorous photos and status updates on Bella's Facebook page to notify her, including selfies and pictures of the phone in a holding "cell." They made several puns about the phone being "charged" and waiting to be "released." When Bella arrived at the station to collect her phone, officers recognized her from her Facebook photos. She was unaware of their social media activity until they showed her, and found their approach amusing. Following the incident, Bella secured her phone with a password.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was killed after getting caught in a fight between two adult male hippos at the Isimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. While two male hippos were fighting, one of them grabbed the baby hippo in its jaws and threw it into the air. The calf's mother, who had previously been protecting it from sub-adults and younger hippos, had stayed with her herd during the fight, possibly for her own safety. Despite the mother's attempt to rescue her baby by attacking the aggressor's neck, the sub-adult hippo bit down harder and flung the calf into the air. The incident was witnessed by Stacey Farrell, a 30-year-old tour operator, and the baby hippo died from its injuries several hours later.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, has been listed for £575,000, which is significantly below market value for the area. The catch is that the property has only three years remaining on its lease. The cost breaks down to approximately £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month, comparable to rental rates in the area. The 1,990 sq/ft property needs modernization but could be worth up to £6 million if the lease is extended. The current freeholder is believed to be the Welcome Trust, and extending the lease to 90 years would cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million. It's one of two maisonettes being sold with short leases, with the second, larger property priced at £595,000. Estate agents note that such short-lease properties rarely come to market, and the listing has generated significant interest despite the upcoming election.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting point-of-sale registers at 8,000 stores across the US (7,000) and Canada (1,000). The outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, prevented stores from processing credit card payments. In response, many locations began giving away free drinks and food to customers, while some stores chose to close early instead. The incident sparked significant social media activity, with customers sharing their experiences of receiving free beverages. The outage was eventually resolved, with Starbucks announcing stores would return to "business as usual" the following day. Notably, this technical issue occurred just after Starbucks had reported record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

The Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit has reported that terrorists are using rural areas in West Wales (specifically Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire) for training and radicalization of Muslims. Detective Constable Gareth Jones revealed that while these individuals participate in seemingly normal community activities, they have hidden motives. The passage cites several historical examples, including:

1. In 1998, Abu Hamza allegedly sent 10 extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons
2. In 2005, two 7/7 bombers were spotted white water rafting in North Wales
3. Three Cardiff-based would-be terrorists were arrested for plotting attacks
4. Michael Adebowale, one of Lee Rigby's murderers, studied at the European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder

DC Jones emphasized that terrorism isn't limited to large cities and stressed the importance of community intelligence in combating these activities.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

An Omura's whale, a rare species, was found washed up on a remote beach in Exmouth, Western Australia, following Cyclone Olwyn. This was the first sighting in WA and only the second in Australia. The 5.68m juvenile female was identified through DNA profiling. The discovery was significant as the species, first described scientifically in 2003, was previously feared extinct and little is known about it. Omura's whales typically inhabit Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. They have distinctive features including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass was buried and its skeleton will be recovered later for scientific study and possible museum display.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

The text discusses gender bias in politics, sparked by comments from CEO Cheryl Rios who claimed women shouldn't be president due to their hormones. Rios suggested hormones would make women, like Hillary Clinton, too irrational to lead. The article counters this argument by pointing out that studies show women leaders actually take fewer unnecessary risks than men, and that male hormones have historically impacted leadership decisions negatively.

The passage then broadens to discuss wider gender bias in the workplace, noting that women face both overt and covert discrimination despite their educational achievements. It presents evidence that gender equality benefits everyone, citing improved business performance, better family outcomes, and stronger marriages when leadership and responsibilities are shared between genders.

The article concludes by addressing Rios's threat to move to Canada if Clinton becomes president, ironically noting that Canada already had a female prime minister, Kim Campbell, in 1993.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Robert Hardy, an 89-year-old veteran actor, is selling his extensive collection of over 200 antiques in a £100,000 auction due to downsizing his home. The collection includes notable items such as a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt (estimated £4,000-£6,000), a yew longbow, furniture, paintings, weapons, silverware, chandeliers, and rare books dating back to the 17th century. Hardy, a military historian and longbow expert who studied under J.R.R. Tolkien at Oxford, is known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small," multiple portrayals of Winston Churchill, and as Cornelius Fudge in the Harry Potter films. The auction, consisting of 238 lots, will be held at Dominic Winter auctioneers in Gloucestershire. While expressing sadness about parting with his collection, Hardy hopes the new owners will derive as much joy from the items as he has.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Michael Scott Shemansky is wanted as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky (57), who was found dead in their shared home in Winter Garden after he failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son. The body was discovered following a well-being check requested by an out-of-state family member. Shemansky has a history of mental illness, including bipolar disorder, and was previously on parole for battery on law enforcement. He was living with his mother while going through divorce proceedings, and his wife had previously filed a domestic violence injunction against him. Neighbors suggest that divorce-related paperwork received Friday may have triggered the incident. Police have recovered the murder weapon but haven't disclosed how Sandra Shemansky was killed. The suspect was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Eugene, United States, has been awarded the hosting rights for the 2021 IAAF World Championships, marking the first time the event will be held in the USA. The IAAF Council made this decision by bypassing the normal bidding process, viewing it as a unique strategic opportunity. While Eugene had previously lost its bid to host the 2019 championships to Doha, Qatar, the IAAF was convinced by a recent presentation that Eugene could successfully host the event. IAAF President Lamine Diack noted this decision was supported by a coalition of public authorities, private sector, the National Olympic Committee, NBC, and public enthusiasm. This wasn't unprecedented, as the 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, was also awarded without a bidding process.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model, was jailed for 16 years for her role in the death of Mehmet Hassan, a 56-year-old professional gambler. Granger targeted Hassan at a London casino, using her looks to befriend him. After being showered with gifts and dining at expensive restaurants, she accompanied Hassan to his flat one night and left the door unlocked for her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and accomplice Nicholas Chandler. The two men tied up Hassan and kicked him to death while searching for his gambling winnings. They stole £3,000, a TV, and a mobile phone. Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life with a minimum of 36 years. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter but not murder. The judge described the attack as "pitiless and wicked."

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Cesc Fabregas, Chelsea's midfielder, is experiencing his characteristic second-half season decline in form. After an impressive start with Chelsea following his £30M transfer, where he recorded 15 Premier League assists by mid-January, his performance has significantly dropped, managing just one assist in his last five games. This pattern was previously noted by Barcelona when he left, stating he typically shows "downward trends" late in seasons. The decline was evident in Spain's recent 2-0 defeat to Holland, where he received poor ratings. Despite his current slump, Fabregas remains important to Chelsea's title chase, with manager Jose Mourinho hoping for a resurgence as they need approximately six wins from their remaining nine games. Fabregas is also pursuing Thierry Henry's Premier League assist record of 20, though his current form suggests he may fall short.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

West Ham are in talks to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford from Montego Bay United. Beckford, considered one of the Caribbean's top prospects, impressed coaches during a two-week trial at West Ham's academy. While he has offers from Belgian clubs, West Ham appears close to securing his signature. Additionally, the club announced that season tickets at their new Olympic Stadium will start at £289, making them the cheapest in the Premier League as they aim to fill the 54,000-seat venue for the 2016-17 season.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Mike Lane, a 40-year-old joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, was attacked by balaclava-wearing protesters during a hunt that was following an artificial scent. The assault occurred at Everleigh, near Amesbury, where approximately 15 protesters confronted the hunting party. Lane was kicked in the head, suffered concussion, broken teeth, and subsequent memory loss. Despite having evidence including video footage, names of saboteurs, car registration numbers, and a photograph of the main suspect, Wiltshire Police dropped the investigation after three months citing insufficient evidence. The victim and hunt supporters expressed disappointment with the police's decision, and the Countryside Alliance is now campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing face coverings to help bring criminals to justice.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Adam Gadahn, a 36-year-old American citizen, was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January. Known as "Azzam the American," he served as Al Qaeda's chief English-language propagandist. Born in California in 1978, he converted to Islam in 1995 and left for Pakistan in 1998. Gadahn appeared in numerous Al Qaeda videos threatening Western interests, criticizing U.S. presidents, and encouraging Muslim attacks on American targets. He was indicted for treason in 2006 and was on the FBI's "Most Wanted Terrorists" list. His role in Al Qaeda included making media strategy recommendations, as evidenced by documents found in Osama bin Laden's compound. The White House noted that Gadahn wasn't specifically targeted in the operation that killed him. He was married to an Afghan woman and reportedly had at least one child.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

A five-year-old Chinese boy named Mai Zizhuo has become a viral sensation due to his exceptional basketball skills. In a widely shared video, he demonstrates impressive abilities including scoring multiple hoops and simultaneously dribbling two basketballs while maintaining eye contact with the camera. Mai has been practicing basketball since age two and a half, and his talents have earned him many fans across China, where basketball is very popular. The video has generated thousands of comments from amazed viewers, with many expressing disbelief at his abilities. The passage also mentions that China's biggest basketball star to date has been Yao Ming, who played for the Houston Rockets from 2002 to 2011.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Tom O'Carroll, a former leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), has become a supporter of the media pressure group Hacked Off. He attended a Hacked Off rally at the Houses of Parliament on February 25, which was chaired by comedian John Cleese. The rally's purpose was to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. PIE was an organization formed in 1974 that campaigned to legalize child sex and was allied with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL). O'Carroll, who was jailed in 1981 for 'corrupting public morals,' was previously a member of NCCL's gay rights sub-committee. Hacked Off, established following the phone-hacking scandal, is campaigning against the Independent Press Standards Organisation and advocates for statutory press regulation as recommended by the Leveson inquiry.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool in Australia was drained on Thursday to serve as an unconventional catwalk for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The fashion label Ten Pieces, run by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, showcased a monochrome unisex collection. The show featured models walking through the empty pool and along the break wall with the ocean as a backdrop. The collection consisted of ten pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways, suitable for day-to-night wear. Guests enjoyed refreshments from Icebergs and Santa Vittoria during the show, which took place on an unseasonably warm 28-degree Celsius day.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Amir Khan, a boxer from Bolton, visited Six Flags Discovery Kingdom safari park in Northern California with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa. During their family day out, they interacted with various animals, including feeding a rare white tiger and posing with giraffes and sea lions. The passage also mentions that Khan announced his next boxing match would be against Chris Algieri on May 30, despite pressure to fight British rival Kell Brook. Khan had also been linked to potential fights with Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman before making this decision.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a 16-year-old Palestinian teenager who was murdered by three Israelis in July, had his name briefly included on an Israeli memorial wall at Mount Herzl that commemorates fallen soldiers and terrorism victims. His name appeared as Israel prepared for its memorial day, but was subsequently removed following objections from both his family and Almagor, an Israeli victims' rights organization. His father, Hussein Abu Khdeir, objected because he hadn't given permission and didn't want his son's name listed among "soldiers of the occupation." Almagor opposed the inclusion because they considered the teen's death a "rogue attack" rather than an act of terrorism. Following these complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel removed Abu Khdeir's name from both the physical memorial and their website.

The passage describes a humorous interaction between a young boy and a cat, captured on video by YouTube user Lionel Hutz in California. The boy repeatedly attempts to use the cat's belly as a pillow in their garden. Each time the boy lies down on the cat, the feline moves to a different spot, with the boy following and trying again. This happens three times before the cat finally retreats indoors. The story ends on a positive note, with a later video showing the boy and cat reconciling as the child feeds treats to the pet.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Robert Kushner, a 32-year-old witness in a Philadelphia police corruption trial, lost his varsity coaching position at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past marijuana dealing. During his testimony, he claimed that undercover officers on trial had stolen $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. While Kushner had passed a background check when hired in 2010 (with his 2007 charges being expunged), he had subsequent legal issues including a 2011 arrest resulting in four years probation and a 2008 DUI conviction. The trial involves six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering, whose defense lawyers claim the government's case relies on testimony from 19 dishonest drug dealers and a former corrupt officer.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

An explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou, China's Fujian province, caused a large fire and injured six people. The facility produces paraxylene (PX), a potentially carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility following an oil leak, with five people injured by broken glass. Over 600 firefighters responded and contained the fire. The same plant had experienced a previous explosion in 2013. The facility was originally planned for Xiamen but was relocated to Zhangzhou after protests in 2007 due to pollution concerns. PX plants in China have been controversial, sparking protests in various cities despite demonstrations being illegal in the country.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Jack Grealish, a young Aston Villa player, insists on wearing his socks low just above his shinpads despite referees' requests to pull them up. This is due to a lifelong superstition he refuses to change. He wears children's-sized shinpads, though they're not easily visible. Grealish made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR, and while pleased with the opportunity, he was disappointed with the game's outcome. His manager indicated he deserved the start, which boosted Grealish's confidence, and he hopes to secure more starts before the season ends.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has been diagnosed with "global and irreversible brain damage" according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. While no longer in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive and does not react to visitors or voices. This contradicts recent statements made by her father Bobby Brown, who claimed she was "awake" during a performance. According to a family attorney, while she has been moved from ICU and may have a long life ahead, she is beginning a rehabilitation process, and the quality of her life remains uncertain. The family statement clarified that Bobby Brown was in an "emotional state" when he made his comments about her condition improving.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Russia took a 2-0 lead in their Fed Cup tie against Germany through two singles victories. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova defeated Sabine Lisicki in three sets (4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3), saving a match point in the second set. Earlier, Svetlana Kuznetsova had beaten Julia Goerges in straight sets. Despite Pavlyuchenkova's 13 double faults, Lisicki's 63 unforced errors proved decisive in the match. Russia now needs just one win from Sunday's three matches to reach the final and potentially claim their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

New South Wales residents are being warned to prepare for another potential storm system, following recent severe weather. An east coast low weather system, similar to the one that caused extensive damage last week, is predicted to hit from Thursday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is still dealing with over 4,000 outstanding jobs from last week's storm, which generated 24,196 requests for assistance. The new system is expected to primarily affect the state's northern regions, unlike last week's storm. The Hunter region, which was severely impacted by the previous storm, is of particular concern to emergency services. The Bureau of Meteorology predicts the rainfall will increase and peak between Thursday and Saturday, with the main impacts expected in the state's northeast and southeast Queensland. The SES is working to complete outstanding jobs before the new system arrives, with over 1,000 personnel deployed across NSW, including 200 from other states.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model known for appearing in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, denied media reports that she attempted suicide. While Italian media claimed she tried to take her own life and was found by her mother in her Milan apartment, Moric explained she was hospitalized after a domestic accident where she fell due to low blood pressure, resulting in head injuries and bruising. She shared photos of her bruises on Instagram and assured her 40,000+ followers she was recovering well. The passage also mentions her previous marriage to Fabrizio Corona, a controversial paparazzi photographer who was jailed for celebrity blackmail, with whom she has a son named Carlos Maria, born in 2002.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

A YouGov survey for the Sunday Times revealed public preferences for the second royal baby's name of Kate and William. If the baby is a girl, Diana is the favorite choice (12% of respondents), followed by Alice and Charlotte (9% each). For a boy, James leads with 13%, followed by Alexander. Of the 2,200 people polled, 25% hoped for a girl, while only 3% wanted a boy. The poll also showed strong public support (68%) for William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job. The name Diana is particularly favored as it would honor William's late mother, Princess Diana, and has generated supportive comments on social media.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

A suicide bombing occurred in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 people and wounding 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker. The attack targeted a group of protesters who were heading to join a larger rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack, and no other group has claimed responsibility. The bombing took place around 10 a.m. local time.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Dani Alves, a Brazilian right-back, is set to leave Barcelona after rejecting their final contract offer. He has been with Barcelona for seven years, during which he won four Spanish titles and two Champions League trophies. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, announced that negotiations have ended after Barcelona offered a three-year extension that required Alves to play in 60% of the club's matches. She expressed frustration that Barcelona waited until April to consider renewing his contract.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Pablo Osvaldo, currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has publicly encouraged Italian football stars Andrea Pirlo and Francisco Totti to join him at the Argentine club. Speaking to Corriere dello Sport, Osvaldo, who has scored three goals in six games for Boca, believes both players would suit the club's style due to their "South-American" playing abilities. He suggests that the fans at La Bombonera stadium would enthusiastically welcome both players. Osvaldo has played with many top players throughout his career but specifically chose Pirlo and Totti as ideal additions to Boca Juniors.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, experienced a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse Merrion Square during a race at Wincanton. The fall became an internet sensation, being viewed hundreds of thousands of times online. Despite the dramatic nature of the accident, Ferguson only sustained a minor cut to his nose and returned to his regular duties at Paul Nicholls's yard the next day, including mucking out stables and riding. Ferguson maintained a positive attitude about the incident, noting that while he couldn't avoid the fall, he was fortunate to escape serious injury. His fellow jockeys showed concern for his well-being, and he gained additional social media followers as a result of the incident.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain, posted a photo of himself dressed as Iron Man on Instagram, coinciding with the release of "Avengers: Age of Ultron." The rugby player's career began at Wasps in 2002, where he played for eight seasons before embarking on international stints with Stade Francais (France), Ricoh Black Rams (Japan), and the Highlanders (New Zealand) between 2009 and 2012. After returning to Wasps in 2012, Haskell has achieved over 100 appearances for the club and earned 57 caps for England's national team.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

The wide-leg trouser is emerging as a key fashion trend for SS15 (Spring/Summer 2015), offering an alternative to the long-dominant skinny jean. The style comes in various forms including denim, cropped, printed, and striped versions. While potentially intimidating, especially for shorter people, the key to wearing wide-leg trousers successfully lies in proper styling: pairing them with high heels to elongate the leg, keeping the top half simple with basic knits or shirts, and paying attention to proportions. Denim is considered the easiest way to adopt the trend, as demonstrated by Gucci's seventies-inspired collection. High-street brands like Topshop have followed suit with their own versions, while luxury brands like Celine and Stella McCartney have created dressier variations. The trend represents a revival of a seventies style and offers a versatile wardrobe update that doesn't depend on weather conditions.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

The University of Michigan initially canceled a screening of "American Sniper" after 200+ students petitioned against it, citing concerns about the film's portrayal of the Middle East. However, this decision faced backlash and a counter-petition emerged. The university's Vice President for Student Life, E. Royster Harper, reversed the cancellation, acknowledging it was a mistake and inconsistent with the university's values of freedom of expression. The film will be shown as planned, with "Paddington" offered as an alternative screening. The film features Bradley Cooper as Chris Kyle, the most lethal sniper in U.S. military history, who was killed in 2013 at a Texas shooting range.

The passage describes an incident where two French tourists (aged 18 and 24) attempted to harm a quokka on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, on April 3. They used an aerosol spray and a lighter to create a flame that made contact with the animal. While the quokka survived the incident with only minor singeing, the two men were charged with animal cruelty, evicted from the island, and are scheduled to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. The passage also notes that quokkas, which are cat-sized animals, can be found on small islands off Western Australia's coast, particularly Rottnest Island and Bald Island.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer who performed in prominent New York venues like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar during the 1930s-40s, recently saw footage of herself dancing for the first time. Though she had performed alongside famous entertainers like Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra, and had been filmed during her career, she had never seen the footage as all her memorabilia had been lost. Mark Cantor from jazz-on-film.com and volunteers showed her "soundies" (early music videos) of her performances at her nursing home, which she found "fabulous."

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

The tradition of washing one's own car in Britain appears to be declining. According to a survey by OSV of 1,100 adults:
- One-third of men have never washed their own car
- Three-quarters of women never wash their own car
- Only 12% of men who do wash their cars do it regularly
- Only 5% have asked their children to wash cars for pocket money

Several factors contribute to this decline:
- Sunday shopping and live football on TV
- Rise of hand car washes
- Larger vehicles (4x4s and off-roaders) being harder to clean

The study found geographical and brand differences:
- Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield residents are most likely to wash their cars weekly
- Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh residents are least likely
- Audi, Toyota, and BMW owners are most likely to wash their own vehicles
- Range Rover, Peugeot, and Mercedes owners are least likely

While car washing increases during holidays (15 million cars cleaned during Easter break), one in four people only did it to get out of the house.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Martin Skrtel discusses Steven Gerrard's upcoming departure from Liverpool FC. Gerrard is preparing for an FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with the possibility of playing his final Liverpool game in the FA Cup final on his birthday (May 30) before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel praises Gerrard as one of the world's best players and acknowledges his helpful role in Skrtel's integration at Liverpool since 2008. While Skrtel believes Liverpool will be different without Gerrard, he's confident the club has players who can step up to fill the void. Both players are available to return to the lineup after serving three-match bans following a Manchester United match.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Jack Nicklaus, at age 75, scored a hole-in-one during the Masters par-3 contest at Augusta National, hitting an ace on the 130-yard fourth hole. He was playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. This was Nicklaus's first hole-in-one at Augusta. On the same day, there were a total of five holes-in-one, matching a 2002 record. Camilo Villegas also scored two aces but lost the contest to Kevin Streelman in a playoff. The passage notes that Nicklaus is a six-time Masters champion, winning his first green jacket in 1963 and his last in 1986, and is one of five players to complete the career grand slam.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Multiple tornadoes were reported in Kansas on Wednesday night, including one near Goddard (close to Wichita) and three near Aetna. The storms also affected Missouri, with a possible tornado touching down in Potosi, causing wind damage and flooding. CNN's severe weather expert Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are particularly dangerous. The severe weather included hail damage, with baseball-sized hail reported in Farmington. The National Weather Service forecasted more storms for Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris during a weapons sting operation on April 2. Bates claims he accidentally used his gun instead of his taser. At the hearing, the judge allowed Bates to vacation in the Bahamas, which prompted criticism from Harris's family. The case has raised questions about Bates' qualifications, with allegations that he received preferential treatment due to his donations to the agency and friendship with the sheriff. The Tulsa World reported claims that supervisors were told to forge Bates' training records, though the sheriff's office denies this. Bates' preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2, and two deputies involved in Harris's arrest have been reassigned due to threats.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Conor McGregor, a 26-year-old Irish fighter, is preparing for a featherweight title fight against champion Jose Aldo scheduled for July 11 in Las Vegas. McGregor recently got a new tiger tattoo on his stomach, adding to his existing chest tattoo of a gorilla eating a heart. The passage describes tension between the fighters, with McGregor claiming Aldo lacks motivation to defend his title, which would be Aldo's eighth defense. During a promotional tour in Dublin, McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt in front of 5,000 fans, highlighting their fractious relationship ahead of their upcoming fight.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott was filmed skolling (quickly drinking) a schooner of beer at an Australian Rules function, which sparked controversy. While the crowd cheered him on, anti-drinking campaigners criticized his actions. Julie Robert, a cultural studies professor, called it "problematic," arguing that it glorified binge drinking and reinforced negative masculine stereotypes around alcohol consumption. Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, highlighting his commitment to fitness and health. The incident occurred when UTS Bats coach Simon Carradous asked Abbott to drink, which he completed in about six seconds. Critics argued that while drinking is part of Australian tradition, Abbott should have considered current concerns about binge drinking, unlike in previous eras when former PM Bob Hawke demonstrated similar behavior.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Indiana experienced a significant increase in HIV cases in Scott County, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases, up from 106 the previous week. The outbreak occurred among intravenous drug users, primarily related to the use of the painkiller Opana. In response, Governor Mike Pence approved a 30-day needle exchange program on March 26, despite generally opposing such programs. Through this program, 5,322 clean syringes were provided to 86 participants, with about 1,400 used syringes returned. The state legislature was considering legislation to allow needle exchange programs in 23 Indiana counties with high hepatitis C rates. The program's future remained uncertain due to political concerns about promoting drug use, and funding issues stemming from a federal ban on public funding for needle exchange programs since 1989.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

A devoted Arsenal fan created and administered a football club exam to his girlfriend Saskia, grading it with a red pen like a school test. The exam included multiple choice questions, tables, and written sections about Arsenal Football Club, with questions covering topics like match scores, player positions, and team history. Saskia scored 43.5 out of 50 (87%), earning an A grade. Her boyfriend jokingly commented that he "will not be dumping" her due to her good performance. Saskia shared the test on Twitter (@saskiaisabxlla), which generated mixed reactions - some praised her knowledge and called her boyfriend a "legend," while others thought he took things too far. She received particular praise for her creative answers, including her comparison of Alexis Sanchez to Eden Hazard, though she struggled with some player positions and lineup questions.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover informant for the DEA for 27 years after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s. He assisted in major operations that led to the prosecution of significant figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite being promised US citizenship in exchange for his work, Toro now faces deportation after retiring due to health issues. He wasn't paid for his work, and his temporary visa expired on January 1. Toro fears returning to Colombia, stating he would be killed within hours if deported. His former DEA handler, Mike McManus, supports his right to stay in the US, calling the situation "government bureaucracy at its worst." Currently, Toro remains in limbo, unable to obtain a green card or passport, and cannot collect social security benefits without proper documentation.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

A 14-year-old Indian girl set herself on fire, suffering 70% burns, after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village in Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh. The incident occurred when she went outside her house to relieve herself. After the attack, she used kerosene to set herself on fire, and her brother found her and doused the flames. The accused men have been arrested.

The passage connects this incident to broader issues of sexual assault in India, specifically referencing the banned documentary "India's Daughter" about Jyoti Singh, a 23-year-old student who was fatally gang-raped on a bus in Delhi. Her death sparked widespread protests in India and internationally, leading to the conviction and death sentences of four men, while one died in custody and a minor received three years in a reformatory institution.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is preparing for a derby match against Manchester City at Old Trafford. He has ruled out both Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw from participating, stating they are not fit enough to play despite van Persie claiming he was ready. Van Gaal expresses his dream of winning the derby, noting that a victory would put United in contention for third place in the table and help them avoid Champions League qualifying fixtures. He acknowledges the importance of controlling aggression, referencing lessons learned from their previous 1-0 loss to City. Van Gaal also expresses appreciation for the United fans' support at Old Trafford, where he will experience his first home Manchester derby as United manager.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Arsenal and Liverpool fans staged a protest against high ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. The protest was triggered by the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal announcement, while ticket prices remained high at £64 for the cheapest seats at this match. Fans from both clubs, organized by groups including Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement, Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly, and Spion Kop 1906, displayed banners inside and outside the stadium. The protesters expressed concern about rising costs making football inaccessible to working-class supporters, with organizers warning that a generation of fans could be lost if prices aren't reduced. The protest highlighted the disconnect between the Premier League's wealthy TV deals and the high costs faced by match-going fans.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

A newborn baby named Star Reader was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a rare liver condition affecting 1 in 16,000 babies, shortly after birth in Barnsley, West Yorkshire. After noticing her persistent jaundice (yellowing skin), and following an unsuccessful operation to unblock her bile ducts, doctors determined she needed a liver transplant to survive. When both parents, Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave, were found to be unsuitable donors, the baby's maternal aunt, Shanell Reader (who is Jade's twin sister), volunteered to donate part of her liver. The transplant operation took place in November, and after six weeks in hospital, Star made a good recovery. She will require ongoing blood tests and anti-rejection medication for life, but can now live normally thanks to her aunt's donation.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Chelsea players participated in Audi's football challenge, where Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake competed against Loic Remy and Willian in various car-related challenges. The competition consisted of three rounds: first, shooting balls into a car's boot from close range (won by Hazard/Ake 5-3); second, playing tennis over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus as a net (won by Hazard/Ake 6-0); and finally, shooting balls into convertible Audis from long range (won by Remy/Willian). During the final challenge, Willian accidentally broke a car's wing mirror with one of his shots. Despite winning the last round, Remy and Willian lost the overall competition to Hazard and Ake.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive, was involved in a fatal crash in December 2013 where he drove his pickup truck across a median at over 100mph, killing Amanda Murphy (24, eight months pregnant) and Jason Timmons (29) in New Hampshire. While prosecutors claimed Dellinger told investigators he was trying to kill himself, he later stated in court that he had "never been suicidal." Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for the deaths of the couple and their unborn baby. His defense cited issues with Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug overdose, Prozac, and multiple sclerosis. He faces 12-24 years in prison. The crash was so severe that the medical examiner compared the victims' injuries to those from a plane crash. Dellinger was a former executive at several major companies including PPG Industries Inc., Sprint Corp., and General Electric Co., and had substantial financial assets including properties worth $3 million.

Here's a concise summary of the core information from the passage:

Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for killing her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, by poisoning him with salt through his feeding tube. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed anger on Facebook about the sentence, hoping she would be placed in general population and stating she showed no emotion during sentencing. The judge noted that Spears suffered from mental illness but called the crime "unfathomable in its cruelty." Prosecutors, who sought the maximum sentence of 25 years to life, argued that Spears made her son ill for attention and documented his medical struggles on social media. Throughout his life, Garnett endured multiple hospitalizations and unnecessary medical procedures. Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield, Illinois is facing two major challenges: an unflattering review in National Geographic magazine and potential budget cuts. Scientists have created the largest single high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the night sky (approximately 150 times the area of the full moon). This is part of a larger five-year Dark Energy Survey (DES) project that aims to eventually map 12.5% of the sky. The map was created using the Dark Energy Camera, a 570-megapixel device mounted on the Victor M. Blanco telescope in Chile.

Dark matter, which makes up about 80-85% of the universe's matter, can't be directly observed but is detected through its gravitational effects on galaxies. The University of Manchester team, led by Dr. Sarah Bridle, analyzed 130 million telescope images to create the map, which shows how dark matter corresponds to galaxy formation. The map reveals large filaments of matter where galaxies cluster and cosmic voids where few galaxies exist.

The project's ultimate goal is to understand how dark matter's distribution changes over time, which could help explain the nature of dark energy and its role in the universe's expansion.
